newsitem.title: USA: Alaska Rangers find body of missing British hiker.
newsitem.headline: Alaska Rangers find body of missing British hiker.

text.p: Wrangell-St. Elias National Park rangers on Sunday found the body of a British hiker missing since last week, the National Park Service said.
The body of David Richard Harrison, 31, of Shrewsbury, England, was found in a ravine near Dixie Pass in the remote park. Officials believed he died from a fall.
The statewide search for him started September 2, when his father, Peter Harrison of Lancashire, England, reported that his son had not returned to his job teaching math at a private school.
The search was hindered by the lack of information about Harrison's planned trek, the Park Service said. He had failed to register or leave an itinerary with Wrangell-St. Elias rangers.
Neither is required at 13- million-acre (5,260,000 hectares) Wrangell-St. Elias, the largest U.S. national park, but both are recommended, Park Service officials said.
"It is difficult to track visitors to Alaska who do not have a specific itinerary," Wrangell-St. Elias chief ranger Jay Wells said in a news release.
"After several days of intensive investigative work the search area for this case was limited from a state-wide search to a Park-wide search, and finally, to a particular drainage."

Searchers tracked Harrison's movements after learning of postcard sent to his father that mentioned plans to hike in the park and a credit-card charge made to a transportation company in the area, officials said.
They also combed through maps that Harrison had left at an acquaintance's home in Anchorage, they said.
Harrison's hike took him along a trail that is well-established in the beginning but becomes obscure near Dixie Pass, Park Service spokesman John Quinley said.
